MR LOKE WENG CHEE


    

Tributes on Retirement
(Announcement by Mr. Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: I have to inform Hon. Members that Mr Loke Weng Chee, Clerk of the Legislative Assembly, retired from its service on the 18th day of May, 1965, on attaining the age limit of 55 years. Mr Loke joined Government Service in early 1931 and was in April 1947 drafted into the service of the Singapore Legislature which he has served continuously from then until his retirement. Mr Loke became Clerk of the Legislative Assembly in March 1957.

    I first came to know Mr Loke as a Member of this House in 1959. I found him courteous and always willing to listen to and advise those seeking help. As Speaker, I found Mr Loke very knowledgeable in matters concerned

Column: 807

with Parliamentary practice and procedure. He was completely dedicated to his work and to the fulfilment of the duties of his post as Clerk of the Assembly in the best Parliamentary traditions.

    I shall miss him but I console myself with the thought that he has left behind him in the service of the Assembly others similarly imbued with a sense of dedication to duty.

    May I take this opportunity of wishing Mr, and Mrs Loke many happy years of retirement.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, on behalf of the Government Benches, I would like to associate ourselves with the sentiments you have expressed. Mr Loke Weng Chee, as Clerk of the Legislative Assembly, has led us through a period of Parliamentary and Constitutional development in the history of Singapore. In this sense, therefore, his contribution towards our Constitutional progress is considerable.

    As Clerk of the Assembly, Mr Loke has to be correct in his attitude, not only to Members on the Opposition Benches but also to Members on the Government Benches. And from our observation of his conduct in the affairs of the House, Mr Loke has been scrupulously fair to both sides. This, I am quite sure, the Prime Minister himself can attest to, as he has been on the Opposition Benches as well as being on the Government Benches today, and during this period Mr Loke was Clerk of the Assembly.

    I would like, Mr Speaker, again to associate ourselves with your sentiments that Mr, and Mrs Loke enjoy a peaceful and a happy retirement, although knowing Mr Loke as we do, that he looks far younger than his age, we believe he at some future date could put himself to more active service in some other way.

    Mr Lim Huan Boon (Bukit Merah): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, on behalf of my colleagues, congratulate Mr Loke Weng Chee, the former Clerk of this House, on the service rendered by him during the last 34 years?

Column: 808



    Sir, although most of my colleagues, including myself, are new to this House in regard to many rules and procedures of the Assembly, we did really have an interesting time with Mr Loke during the last two years of his term of service. Besides the proficiency and high efficiency in his work, he is a man of fine character, without prejudice whatsoever. He has been very friendly and fair to us, very patient with us, and especially has been very helpful to me personally whenever I, as the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, called for a meeting.

    Sir, it is therefore my sincere hope that any successor of Mr Loke will follow his example so that, through him, our opinions can be freely lodged and discussed. And it is the Government's responsibility to see that this fine tradition will flourish and be preserved.

    Once again, Mr Speaker, let me thank Mr Loke for his assistance and guidance given to us during his time, and we wish him to enjoy himself during the remaining years of his life.

RESIGNATION OF MEMBER
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


2.37 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: It is my painful duty to make this announcement to this House. Ten minutes before I came into this Chamber, the Member for Hong Lim came into my Chambers and tendered his resignation to me effective as from today. Under the Constitution and under the Standing Orders, my duty as Speaker is clear; I accepted his resignation. But while discussing the matter of his resignation, the Member for Hong Lim suggested to me that I read out the letter of resignation which he has sent to me. It is a fairly lengthy document and it contains a number of matters which do not concern me as Speaker of this Assembly. I told this to Mr Ong Eng Guan. I told him that it was no part of my function as Speaker of this House to read out or to acquaint the House of the reasons for his resignation. He has other courses open to him which, no doubt, he will avail himself of .

WOODBRIDGE HOSPITAL
(Vacancies of Junior Hospital Attendants)


    1. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health when the ruling of the Industrial Arbitration Court, that vacancies of Junior Hospital Attendants at Woodbridge Hospital should be filled, will be implemented.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Health): I am replying on behalf of the Minister.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the ruling of the Industrial Arbitration Court made on 20th August, 1964, that all remaining vacancies of Hospital Attendants at Woodbridge Hospital should be filled not later than 31st October, 1964, was duly implemented by the Ministry. It should be stated, however, that whilst no difficulty was encountered in filling 19 vacancies for males, there are still 7 vacancies for female Hospital Attendants, although 40 were selected out of 237 applications to fill 14 vacancies. This situation arose either through refusal to take up offers of appointment after selection, or resignation.

    The Ministry has now initiated a second recruitment exercise for the filling of these 7 vacancies of female Hospital Attendants.

LAND ACQUISITION BILLS
(Statement by the Minister for Law)


2.44 p.m.

    The Minister for Law (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, Members will recollect that in June last year we introduced two complementary Bills to amend the law relating to the acquisition of land for public purposes. The Land Acquisition (Amendment) Bill, which was taken through on a Certificate of Urgency, froze the position of appeals pending the enactment of substantial alterations to the law embodied in the Land Acquisition (Amendment No. 2) Bill, which was referred to the Select Committee for study.

    The main provision in the Land Acquisition (Amendment No. 2) Bill is to ensure that increases in land values as a result of public development should not benefit the owner, but should benefit the community at large. The Bill aimed to save the Government from having to give land-owners windfall gains and increases in value as a result of public expenditure incurred in the area. Since the Bill was introduced into the House, further consideration has been given to the problems of urban redevelopment, and, in particular, to the pressures from private developers on the old squatter settlements in the urban and semi-urban areas. Unable to evict squatters and tenants because of the freezing of certain clauses of the Control of Rent Ordinance, private developers are finding it profitable to pay compensation to squatters to move out of the areas they have been living in for many years.

    A social problem is created in that quite a number of these communities, after taking compensation, have moved out into the outer rural areas, adding to the Government's difficulties in providing water, electricity, roads, rails and other social amenities at high cost in remote areas.

Column: 812



    It is now proposed that where private development necessitates the removal of these old established kampongs in the urban and semi-urban areas, the Government should have the power to acquire a portion of the land sufficient for enough low-cost housing units to be put up to re-house families of Singapore citizens who have been there since 1958. In this way, when urban re-development takes place, all sections of the community will share in the advantages of re-development. In order that such schemes can be practicable and do not become prohibitive in cost to the Government, compensation rates for the acquisition of a portion of the land for re-housing should take into account what the developers would have had to pay these squatters to move out into other areas, and the fact that the Government will be undertaking the responsibility not only of low-cost housing for all citizens regardless of their race, but also in the case of Malays who are Singapore citizens and whose family incomes are less than $200 per month, or perpetual subsidy of 20 per cent of the rent.

    The State Advocate-General's Chambers have looked into these matters and have advised that, in order to remove any doubts on the validity of this new legislation, it will be necessary for the Malaysian Parliament to exempt such a Bill from the operation of Article 13 of the Constitution, which provides that:

    `no law shall provide for the compulsory acquisition or use of property without adequate compensation.'

    Representation will be made to the Central Government for such an exemption provision to be passed in Parliament in order that these projects can be carried out in Singapore without any uncertainty about the constitutional validity of the formula for compensation.

    In this context, it may be relevant to note that the Indian Government, when faced with a similar problem in connection with their plans for land reform, had to effect a constitutional amendment to a corresponding provision in the Indian Constitution in order that their land reforms could be implemented.

Column: 813



    It is the Government's intention to re-introduce this Bill after the necessary additional provisions have been added for acquisition of land under private developers for re-housing of squatters who are Singapore citizens and have been there since 1958. If the Government were to carry the responsibility of re-housing squatters arising out of private development without being held to ransom by private landlords, then we must ensure that land acquired for public projects can be obtained at economic cost so that the private landlord, while he does not lose, would not gain any windfalls as a result of Government development expenditure and because the Government is undertaking the burden of public re-housing of their encumbered land. Increase in value attributable to public expenditure in laying sewers, roads and supplying community facilities in the area should not go into the pockets of a few land-owners who have done nothing to add to the value of the land, hut should accrue to the State for the benefit of the whole community.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government expects to re-introduce the Bill with necessary amendments at the appropriate time at the next sitting of the Legislative Assembly.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have said that the Member should not make a speech. If he wants to ask questions, he may do so. And he must not preface his question by making a speech. Let him go into his question direct.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Law has said that the Government intend to look after the interests of the squatters and not allow their interests to be exploited by the landowners. What are the interests he was referring to?

    Mr Speaker: The Minister would like to answer that?

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, while we say we are looking after the squatters' interest, we, in fact, mean that we would not allow the landowner just to turf out the squatters without any compensation. The Government itself is paying compensation. That is what is meant.

BARISAN EXPRESS CRITICISES SPEAKER'S RULING


    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I wish to draw your attention, Mr Speaker, and the attention of the House to an article which was printed in the Barisan Express dated 12th of June, 1965. The article states briefly that they had intended to move at this sitting of the Assembly a motion which reads as follows:

    `That this House resolves that the Government of Singapore should urge the Central Government in Kuala Lumpur to achieve honourable peace in North Borneo and Malaya, including Singapore, on the principles as stated below:'

    (1), (2) and so on. And the article goes on to read as follows:

    `What the motion propounds is the correct way to settle the Malaysia issue in order to free the people from imperialist rule and realise a peaceful, prosperous, independent and democratic society. However, the day before yesterday, the Assemblyman of our Party [that is, the Barisan Sosialis] received a note from the Clerk of the Assembly stating that the motion was not allowed by the Speaker to be tabled for debate. The reason is, it criticises the resolution of the House on the question of Malaysia and merger, and discusses internal matters which affect other territories outside Singapore.

    Before receiving the letter, comrade Assemblyman Chia Thye Poh of our Party [that is, the Barisan Sosialis Party] saw the Speaker to express his views about whether or not the motion should be allowed to be debated. According to comrade Chia, as regards the question of criticising Malaysia

Column: 815

and the bogus merger, the fact is that if any constitutional arrangement or any ordinance which is dissatisfactory to the people and has proved to be extremely disadvantageous to the people, the Legislative Assembly should suggest and review revision, repeal such as in the case of the former Rendel Constitution.

    As regards the motion which involves the matters of other territories, it is because Malaysia includes North Borneo territories. So it is impossible that what happens in North Borneo will not affect Singapore at all. Such measures as conscription and increased taxation are clear proofs.'

    The article goes on to criticise that, because of the Standing Orders, 7 days' notice being required before a motion can be moved in the Assembly, the Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen complained that they did not have adequate time in which to present any revised version of the motion which they had presented to you.

    There are two points, Mr Speaker, arising out of this article. The first point is that it is critical of the Speaker's ruling. Whether this criticism of the Speaker's ruling should be published beforehand, before this Assembly meets, or should be discussed in this Chamber is to be judged a breach of privilege or even a reprimand of the Speaker, I leave it to you, Mr Speaker.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the proper procedure, if that is the case, is for a Member from the Government benches or anybody who is complaining to move a motion to that effect, and leave it to me, as Speaker, to decide whether I will allow that motion to be debated without proper notice. I think the Deputy Prime Minister should not go any further than he has actually done. It is possible under our Standing Orders to do that. If the House will bear with me for a minute, I will give them the proper reference.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, under Standing Order 10 (1) (s) :

    `Motions, with or without notice, complaining of a breach of privilege or affecting the powers and privileges of the Assembly or relating to a report of the Committee of Privileges.'

will come after business motions moved by Ministers. The Leader of the House was drawing your attention to this particular report. Meanwhile, Mr Speaker,

Column: 816

Sir, a formal motion is being prepared to be moved immediately after business motions have been moved by Ministers in order that the matter can be properly debated in this House. I think it is important that such criticism of the ruling of the Speaker in an article published in a Barisan journal, the editor of which is a Member of this Assembly, should receive adequate publicity not just in Barisan Express, which is somewhat limited in circulation, but in the more popular channels of public communication.

    Mr Speaker: May I direct the attention of the House to the Standing Orders relating to the Committee of Privileges which appear on pages 44, 45 and 46 of the Standing Orders? Now, I should imagine that the circumstances delineated by the Deputy Prime Minister would come under paragraph 92 (7) (d) (ii) :

    `Such a motion may be moved without notice if the Speaker is satisfied that the matter raised does, prima facie, affect the powers and privileges of the Assembly and has been raised at the earliest opportunity.'

    So that if the motion is moved at the appropriate time and if the mover of the motion satisfies the Speaker that there is a prima facie case and that the matter has been raised at the earliest possible opportunity, then the mover of the motion will be allowed to speak on it. No motion will be put to the House, but it will stand adjourned to the Committee of Privileges for determination by this Committee. Is the position made quite clear to Members?

    Hon. Members indicated assent.

    Mr Speaker: Very well.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: May I carry on, Mr Speaker.

    Mr Speaker: Yes, Dr Toh, provided you do not now touch upon the matters of which you are complaining, you may do so. But if you are going to in any way introduce them, I think it might be somewhat premature. I suggest that we leave it till the proper time when the mover moves the motion.

Column: 817



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I bow to your ruling, Mr Speaker, Sir. One of my colleagues will move the motion relating to the breach of privilege at the proper time.

    But will you permit me to proceed to the second point which I have raised? The second point in the article complains that the Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen do not have adequate time to put in any motion at all to the Legislative Assembly for debate because of the existing Standing Orders. Here, I would like very much to clarify to the House, and to the public in general, and to the Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen in particular, that if they had any real intention to move or debate any particular motion or to ask any questions in this House, there was adequate time. They complain in this article that this Assembly has not met for the last five months. They had five months in which they could have presented to this House any motion which they thought worth while debating or could have asked any questions. How could they say in this same article, in one and the same breath, that because under Standing Orders seven days' notice at least is required before a private Member can ask questions or move a motion they did not have adequate time? I can only conclude that Barisan Sosialis Assemblymen are slow-witted or they have no intention at all to bring up any serious matter for discussion. Therefore, the allegations which they have made in this article are utterly pernicious, false and incomprehensible.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I would like to speak in reply to the Deputy Prime Minister ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have already indicated to the House that there is no right of reply and there is no right to debate on a Ministerial statement. But the Member is at liberty to ask any number of questions he likes provided they arise out of the Ministerial statement. So if the Member will frame his questions, perhaps we might get on with it.

Column: 818



    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Just now the Deputy Prime Minister in his Ministerial statement said that an article in the Barisan Sosialis paper made false allegations with regard to some points. Now, which particular points? Can he make any quotations? Is it not true with regard to the notice that seven days' notice is required?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, the Standing Orders have been published, copies have been issued to Members of this Assembly, and the public knows what the Standing Orders are all about. If Members of the Barisan Sosialis had any real or serious intention - and if they had their wits about them or they were sufficiently intelligent enough - to move a motion for debate in this House, they had five months in which to do it!

    Why do they complain that they do not have adequate time to present a motion? It is true that the Standing Orders say that private Members must give a minimum of seven days' notice. But that did not prevent the Barisan Sosialis from submitting their motions a month ago. What were they doing during the last five months?

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, from what the Deputy Prime Minister has said, one can see that he has not explained which particular part in the article of the Barisan Sosialis is false. He has tried to give the impression that the article in the Barisan was untrue. But he has not been able to give examples and quotations of the untruths. Is it not a fact that he is deliberately using the privilege in this House to create an impression with the public against the ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. I told the Member on the Opposition side that this is a Ministerial statement from the Government Benches and that they may ask questions with no comments on the statement. Any questions relevant to the statement with a view to finding out facts or showing to the Minister that he is mistaken in the Statement are permissible. But no comments on the statement other than those questions, please. Have you finished, Mr Chia Thye Poh?

Perhaps you would like to repeat the question? I did not quite follow it myself.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh(In Mandarin): The Deputy Prime Minister has said that there are certain paragraphs in the Barisan article to the effect that the Assembly have not sat for a few months. Is it not a fact?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, maybe I can be of some assistance to the Member on the other side. I think he may be under some misapprehension that the Standing Orders of this Assembly are like those of the Parliament in Kuala Lumpur. I sympathise with the Member for Jurong, because in Kuala Lumpur if his motion does not come up for debate on a particular sitting of Parliament, it disappears from the Order Paper at the next sitting. But I can assure him that in this Assembly, if for any reasons his motion is not reached at this sitting, it will be carried forward on the Order Paper and will receive precedence and pride of place in the next sitting of the Legislative Assembly. Whatever he raises either by way of question or by way of motion, will be debated. It will never lapse into the limbo of unasked questions and unmoved motions as happened to him, with so much of our sympathy with him in Parliament.

    The Prime Minister: That is the point which my colleagues was trying to make. Had the Member moved a single motion or a single resolution, we would have summoned the Assembly forthwith to debate it. I will give him this offer, Mr Speaker, Sir, It is seriously given now. If he would table any resolution now, today before 4 o'clock, we will meet here this time next week to debate his motion. I give him this categorical assurance. We never run away from our

PINEAPPLE INDUSTRY
(AMENDMENT) BILL

3.10 p.m.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to amend the Pineapple Industry Ordinance, 1957 (No. 15 of 1957)."

    I have here a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Lim Kim San: I hand in to the Clerk His Excellency's permission to proceed with the Bill under a Certificate of Urgency.

    Mr Speaker: Would you take your seat for a while, Mr Minister?

    Mr Lim Kim San resumed his seat.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Lim Kim San, you have produced a Certificate of Urgency signed by His Excellency. It seems to be in order. But you have also to signify his recommendation that this Bill can be proceeded with under Article 43. Have you got that recommendation? If you will so signify from the Floor?
